title: Activity 22: Dash‚Äôs Adventure Series ‚Äì Basketball Challenge & Castle Siege
text:
In this action-packed session, students will tackle two creative missions with Dash: Basketball Challenge and Castle Siege. Each task is designed with increasing difficulty by grade level, allowing students to build their programming logic as they play.
Using Blockly, students will control Dash to move, aim, and launch in order to complete each objective. Along the way, they‚Äôll explore fundamental computer science concepts like sequencing, debugging, conditionals, and loops‚Äîall wrapped inside a fun, interactive story.

title: Activity 22: Dash‚Äôs Adventure Series ‚Äì Basketball Challenge & Castle Siege
text:
In this action-packed session, students will tackle two creative missions with Dash: Basketball Challenge and Castle Siege. Each task is designed with increasing difficulty by grade level, allowing students to build their programming logic as they play.
Using Blockly, students will control Dash to move, aim, and launch in order to complete each objective. Along the way, they‚Äôll explore fundamental computer science concepts like sequencing, debugging, conditionals, and loops‚Äîall wrapped inside a fun, interactive story.

title: Activity 22: Dash‚Äôs Adventure Series ‚Äì Basketball Challenge & Castle Siege
Activity 22: Dash‚Äôs Adventure Series ‚Äì Basketball Challenge & Castle Siege
text:
Materials

Dash Robot (with Launcher add-on)

3 soft balls per robot

Plastic cups, blocks, or small boxes

Tape or tiles for making paths

Tablets with Blockly app

Optional: cones, obstacles, or themed props for story immersion (Note: You can create your own unique story for the kids)

title: Activity 22: Dash‚Äôs Adventure Series ‚Äì Basketball Challenge & Castle Siege
text:
Challenge 1: Dash‚Äôs Basketball Mission üèÄ

Storyline
Story 1: Dash dreams of being a pro basketball player. Today, he‚Äôs stepping up to take 3 shots at the hoop, but he needs your help to get the ball in every time.


Setup

Place a cup or small container at a reasonable distance.

Dash must move to a firing position and attempt to land all 3 balls in the target.

Depending on the grade, students can work with pre-made or self-designed paths.



Grade-Level Breakdown
Grades 1‚Äì2 (Getting Started)
- Use a guided path for Dash.
- Focus on simple commands like forward, turn, and launch.
- One shot at a time, 3 total.
- üîç Focus Skill: Following instructions, cause-and-effect logic.
Grades 3‚Äì4 (Growing Coders)
- Students design the path to the hoop.
- Adjust launch strength to score.
- Use blocks like launch at __%, repeat, and basic conditionals.
- üîç Focus Skill: Adjusting variables, learning loops.
Grades 5‚Äì6 (Code Pros)
- Students must build their own obstacle course and hit all 3 shots using a single sequence of blocks.
- Encourage use of loops, variables, and conditions to optimize.
- üîç Focus Skill: Efficiency, strategic thinking, and testing.

title: Activity 22: Dash‚Äôs Adventure Series ‚Äì Basketball Challenge & Castle Siege
text:
Challenge 2: Dash‚Äôs Castle Siege üè∞

Storyline
A princess is locked inside a castle made of blocks. Dash is on a quest to bring down the gates and rescue her with his launcher, but the walls are tougher than they look.


Setup

Create a ‚Äúcastle‚Äù out of stacked cups or blocks.

Dash will move into range and fire at lower blocks to topple the wall.

Add extra conditions or obstacles for upper levels.



Grade-Level Breakdown
Grades 1‚Äì2 (New Knights)
- Follow a path to the castle.
- Aim and fire to knock down the wall.
- üîç Focus Skill: Object interaction and movement basics.
Grades 3‚Äì4 (Castle Crushers)
- Allow retries with loops.
- Focus on hitting weak points in the wall.
- Use repeat blocks and conditional retries.
- üîç Focus Skill: Recognizing patterns, problem-solving.
Grades 5‚Äì6 (Master Coders)
- Add rules: ‚ÄúIf wall is still up, fire again.‚Äù
- Include extra steps like navigating inside the castle after it falls.
- Must use a complete block sequence with minimal trial edits.
- üîç Focus Skill: Conditional logic, multi-step planning.

title: Activity 22: Dash‚Äôs Adventure Series ‚Äì Basketball Challenge & Castle Siege
text:
Discussion & Reflection
After both challenges, gather the class for a quick debrief. We can ask:

What changes made your shots or launches more accurate?
Did your code work the first time? If not, how did you fix it?
What strategy did you use for loops or conditionals?
What part did you enjoy the most?

title: Activity 22: Dash‚Äôs Adventure Series ‚Äì Basketball Challenge & Castle Siege
text:
Wrap-Up
These themed Dash activities blend creative storytelling with foundational programming skills. By adjusting challenge levels and allowing room for imagination, students stay engaged while learning how to think like a programmer: plan, test, adjust, and try again!

title: Code with Chompers
text:
Code with Chompers


Inspiring future technologists to think computationally!


Explore our engaging and educational activities designed for young digital learners. Learn more about our exciting initiatives on the About page.









For Teachers


Learn about how you can bring Outreach Fellows into your classroom and explore our Activities which can be conducted in classes.

Register to become an Outreach Fellow! Find Activities








For Outreach Fellows


As a Computing Outreach Fellow, you‚Äôll guide engaging activities for students of all ages. Don‚Äôt worry‚Äîclear, step-by-step guides will be at your side to help you throughout the process. Get ready for a rewarding experience!

 Check out the Outreach Fellow Guide! Apply to be a Fellow!





 Back to top

title: About
text: Our goal is to foster an ongoing collaboration between the Department of Computer and Information Science at Allegheny College and Crawford Central elementary schools. This initiative introduces K-6 students to computing concepts, ensuring consistent exposure to STEM from early education.

title: About
text: Our goal is to foster an ongoing collaboration between the Department of Computer and Information Science at Allegheny College and Crawford Central elementary schools. This initiative introduces K-6 students to computing concepts, ensuring consistent exposure to STEM from early education.

title: About
text:
Pennsylvania Education Framework

STEM in Pennsylvania
STEM education in Pennsylvania emphasizes literacy for all students, reflection, iteration, community integration, and partnerships between educators, families, and institutions.


Computer Science Literacy
The current Pennsylvania framework prioritizes grades 7-12, but we aim to bridge this gap by introducing computer science concepts to younger students, aligned with state standards.

Sources

PA Department of Education STEM Guidelines
The Framework for Computer Science 7-12 Program Guidelines

title: Guide for Computing Outreach Fellows
text: Computing outreach involves engaging K-6 students in regular, hands-on computing activities to foster interest and competency in computational skills. This includes introducing students to computational thinking and problem-solving through events, workshops, and classroom activities, and using technologies. The goal is to provide consistent exposure in the computing field in a fun way.

title: Guide for Computing Outreach Fellows

title: Guide for Computing Outreach Fellows
section: What to Expect as a Computing Outreach Fellow
text:
What to Expect as a Computing Outreach Fellow

You will be tasked with activities that will vary depending on the grades you are working with
All activities will be held in groups that can vary depending on the size of the class
Working with younger students ranging from K to 2nd grade, will require to participate in activities that are more based in reading and explain methods of computational skills
Older students from 5th to 6th grade will involve the use of more robotics in activities, requiring fellows to understand how the robots work and how they fit into the activities
You will be given outlines that will guide you through the necessary steps to doing activities

title: Guide for Computing Outreach Fellows
text:
Key Responsibilities

Working with children
Collaborating with faculty at Meadville public schools
Running through and understanding activities beforehand
Reading books that improve students understanding of computational skills
